close_symbols: (if different) the type/struct definition used by irqs (e.g., struct/typedef that defines the object's size and layout)
explanation: The only string.h call in the function is memset(&irqs, 0, sizeof(irqs)). To determine whether this can access beyond the bounds of the object, the analyzer needs the exact declaration and definition of the symbol 'irqs' (its type, storage duration, and size). If 'irqs' is an array or a struct, sizeof(irqs) gives the full object size and memset(&irqs, ...) should be validated against that size; if 'irqs' is a pointer, sizeof(irqs) yields the size of the pointer and memset(&irqs, ...) writes only over the pointer object (potentially different from the programmer's intent). Also include the concrete struct/typedef definition used by irqs (if the declaration references a named type) so the field sizes/layout are known. These symbols are sufficient to decide whether the memset call can write beyond the bounds of the referenced object per the MISRA rule.
